January 1: On this day in 1959, the Soviet Union's Luna 1 became the first human-made object to reach the Moon. It passed within 5,995 kilometers (3,725 miles) of the lunar surface.
January 2: The Kuiper Belt, a region of the solar system beyond Neptune that is filled with small icy bodies, was discovered on this day in 1992 by astronomers David C. Jewitt and Jane Luu.
January 3: In 2004, the Mars Exploration Rover Spirit landed on Mars, beginning its mission to explore the Martian surface and search for signs of past water activity.
January 4: The Hubble Space Telescope, one of the most famous and influential telescopes, was launched into space on this day in 1990. It has provided stunning images and valuable scientific data.
January 5: The New Horizons spacecraft conducted a flyby of Pluto on this day in 2015, becoming the first mission to visit this distant dwarf planet in the outer reaches of the solar system.
January 6: Launched in 2006, the Stardust spacecraft successfully collected samples from the coma of Comet Wild 2. It returned these samples to Earth in 2006, providing valuable insights into the composition of comets.
January 7: The Mars rover Opportunity, part of NASA's Mars Exploration Rover mission, landed on the Red Planet on this day in 2004. It operated for more than 14 years, far surpassing its original mission duration.
January 8: On this day in 2011, the Kepler space telescope discovered its first confirmed exoplanet in the habitable zone—a region where conditions may allow for the presence of liquid water—outside our solar system.
January 9: The MESSENGER spacecraft, launched in 2004, made its first flyby of Mercury on this day in 2008. It later entered orbit around the planet, becoming the first mission to study Mercury up close.
January 10: In 2005, the Huygens probe successfully landed on Saturn's largest moon, Titan, after being released by the Cassini spacecraft. It provided the first direct measurements and images from Titan's surface.
January 11: The Apollo 2 mission, also known as Apollo 17, marked the final crewed mission to the Moon. Astronauts Eugene Cernan and Harrison Schmitt completed their third and final moonwalk on this day in 1972.
January 12: The Voyager 2 spacecraft made its closest approach to Uranus on this day in 1986, capturing detailed images and gathering valuable data about the planet and its moons.
January 13: On this day in 2005, the Huygens probe, which landed on Titan, Saturn's largest moon, transmitted data and images back to Earth, providing insights into this intriguing moon's atmosphere and surface.
January 14: The Galileo spacecraft made its first flyby of Jupiter's moon, Ganymede, on this day in 1992. It provided valuable data about the moon's composition and magnetic field.
January 15: The European Space Agency's Rosetta mission successfully placed the Philae lander on the surface of Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko on this day in 2014. It was the first time a soft landing had been achieved on a comet.
January 16: The Kepler space telescope discovered the first Earth-size exoplanet orbiting within the habitable zone of its star on this day in 2015. Known as Kepler-186f, it raised hopes for the existence of potentially habitable worlds beyond our solar system.
January 17: In 2004, NASA's Mars rover Opportunity landed on the Red Planet, embarking on a mission that far exceeded its original expectations. It played a crucial role in expanding our understanding of Mars' geology and history.
January 18: On this day in 2002, the Mars Odyssey spacecraft began orbiting Mars, where it has since been studying the planet's climate, geology, and potential for supporting future human missions.
January 19: The Apollo 12 mission became the second crewed mission to land on the Moon on this day in 1969. Astronauts Charles Conrad and Alan Bean explored the lunar surface and conducted scientific experiments.
January 20: The SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket, carrying a Tesla Roadster as its payload, was successfully launched on its maiden flight on this day in 2018. It marked a significant milestone in commercial space exploration.
January 21: The European Space Agency's Ariane 5 rocket made its inaugural launch on this day in 1996. It has since become a workhorse for launching satellites and space probes into orbit.
January 22: The NASA spacecraft Voyager 1 took the iconic 'Pale Blue Dot' photograph on this day in 1990. The image shows Earth as a tiny speck in the vastness of space from a distance of about 6 billion kilometers (3.7 billion miles).
January 23: The Chandra X-ray Observatory, NASA's flagship X-ray telescope, was launched on this day in 1999. It has provided remarkable insights into the high-energy universe, including black holes, supernovas, and galaxy clusters.
January 24: The Hubble Space Telescope captured an extraordinary image known as the 'Pillars of Creation' on this day in 1995. The image showcases towering columns of gas and dust in the Eagle Nebula, offering a glimpse into the stellar nursery.
January 25: On this day in 2004, the Mars rover Opportunity landed on the Red Planet, embarking on a mission to study the Martian surface and seek evidence of past water activity.
January 26: The Cassini spacecraft conducted a flyby of Enceladus, one of Saturn's moons, on this day in 2005. It discovered geysers erupting from the moon's south pole, suggesting the presence of a subsurface ocean.
January 27: The Hubble Space Telescope observed the impact of Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 with Jupiter on this day in 1994. The event provided valuable insights into the dynamics and composition of Jupiter's atmosphere.
January 28: NASA's Challenger Space Shuttle exploded shortly after liftoff on this day in 1986, tragically resulting in the loss of all seven crew members. The accident led to a temporary suspension of the Space Shuttle program and significant safety improvements.
January 29: Launched in 2004, the Mars rover Spirit landed on the Red Planet on this day. It conducted geological investigations and operated for over six years before losing communication.
January 30: The Apollo 14 mission successfully landed on the Moon on this day in 1971. Astronauts Alan Shepard and Edgar Mitchell explored the lunar surface, collecting samples and conducting experiments.
January 31: The launch of the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO) took place on this day in 2009. The LRO has been studying the Moon's surface, mapping its topography, and searching for potential landing sites for future missions.
February 1: On this day in 2003, the space shuttle Columbia disintegrated during re-entry into Earth's atmosphere, resulting in the loss of all seven crew members. The tragedy led to a suspension of the Space Shuttle program until safety measures were implemented.
February 2: The first human-made object to reach the asteroid belt, NASA's Pioneer 10, made its closest approach to Jupiter on this day in 1973. It provided valuable data on Jupiter's environment before continuing its journey beyond the solar system.
February 3: The Space Shuttle Challenger's tenth and final mission launched on this day in 1984. It deployed the Solar Maximum Mission satellite, which studied solar flares and their impact on Earth's magnetic field.
February 4: The Soviet Union's Luna 9 spacecraft became the first human-made object to achieve a soft landing on the Moon on this day in 1966. It transmitted the first images of the lunar surface from the landing site.
February 5: The Voyager 1 spacecraft captured the famous 'Family Portrait' image of the solar system on this day in 1990. It showed Earth as a pale blue dot, alongside other planets, as Voyager 1 journeyed towards interstellar space.
February 6: The United States' first successful satellite, Explorer 1, was launched on this day in 1958. It made significant discoveries, including the detection of the Van Allen radiation belts around Earth.
February 7: Launched in 2000, the space shuttle Atlantis delivered the U.S. Destiny Laboratory module to the International Space Station (ISS) on this day. It marked a crucial expansion of the ISS's scientific capabilities.
February 8: The Soviet Union's Luna 20 spacecraft returned to Earth after a successful mission of collecting lunar soil samples on this day in 1972. It marked the first automated soil sample return from the Moon.
February 9: The Kepler space telescope, designed to discover Earth-sized exoplanets, was launched on this day in 2009. It has detected thousands of exoplanet candidates, revolutionizing our understanding of planets beyond our solar system.
February 10: NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO) was launched on this day in 2010. It provides detailed observations of the Sun's atmosphere and helps scientists understand solar activity and its impact on Earth.
February 11: The Hayabusa spacecraft, launched by the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) in 2003, successfully landed on the asteroid Itokawa on this day in 2005. It collected samples and returned to Earth, providing insights into asteroids' composition.
February 12: NASA's Mars rover Curiosity landed on the Red Planet on this day in 2012. It continues to explore Mars, gathering data about its geology, climate, and potential habitability.
February 13: The Soviet Union's Venera 1 spacecraft became the first human-made object to fly by Venus on this day in 1961. Although it did not successfully achieve a Venusian orbit, it provided valuable data during its flyby.
February 14: NASA's Voyager 1 spacecraft captured the 'Pale Blue Dot' image of Earth from a record distance on this day in 1990. The image emphasizes the planet's smallness and fragility in the vastness of space.
February 15: On this day in 2013, a meteor exploded over the Russian city of Chelyabinsk, resulting in a powerful shockwave and numerous injuries. The event highlighted the importance of monitoring near-Earth objects.
February 16: The Hubble Space Telescope captured an image of a stunning galaxy collision known as the
on this day in 2006. It showcases the dramatic effects of gravitational interactions between galaxies.
February 17: NASA's Mars rover Opportunity landed on the Red Planet on this day in 2004, beginning its mission to explore the Martian surface and investigate evidence of past water activity.
February 18: The Soviet Union's unmanned Luna 20 spacecraft completed its mission, returning lunar soil samples to Earth on this day in 1972. It marked another successful sample return from the Moon.
February 19: The space shuttle Discovery, on its STS-63 mission, became the first shuttle to rendezvous with the Russian space station Mir on this day in 1995. It paved the way for future international space collaborations.
February 20: On this day in 1962, astronaut John Glenn became the first American to orbit the Earth. His historic flight, aboard the Friendship 7 spacecraft, lasted nearly five hours.
February 21: The NASA spacecraft Pioneer 11 made its closest approach to Saturn on this day in 1979, capturing remarkable images and data about the ringed planet and its moons.
February 22: The International Space Station's first module, the Russian Zarya module, was launched into space on this day in 1998. It marked the beginning of the construction of the ISS.
February 23: NASA's Stardust spacecraft successfully flew by Comet Wild 2 on this day in 1999. It collected samples from the comet's coma and returned them to Earth, providing insights into the composition of comets.
February 24: Launched in 2011, NASA's Messenger spacecraft became the first mission to orbit Mercury on this day. It studied the planet's composition, geology, and magnetic field until its mission end in 2015.
February 25: The European Space Agency's Rosetta spacecraft made its closest approach to Mars on this day in 2007, utilizing the planet's gravity to gain speed on its way to rendezvous with comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.
February 26: The Hubble Space Telescope detected the first known exoplanet atmosphere on this day in 2007. The exoplanet, named HD 209458b, is a gas giant located about 150 light-years away from Earth.
February 27: The Mars rover Spirit, part of NASA's Mars Exploration Rover mission, landed on the Red Planet on this day in 2004. It operated for over six years, significantly surpassing its original mission duration.
February 28: On this day in 2013, SpaceX's Dragon spacecraft became the first commercially built and operated spacecraft to rendezvous and dock with the International Space Station.
March 1: The Gemini 9A mission, conducted by NASA in 1966, marked the first spacewalk (extravehicular activity) conducted by an American astronaut. Astronaut Gene Cernan spent two hours and nine minutes outside the spacecraft.
March 2: The Soviet Union's Luna 2 spacecraft became the first human-made object to reach the Moon on this day in 1959. It crash-landed on the lunar surface, providing valuable data and paving the way for future missions.
March 3: NASA's Pioneer 10 spacecraft made its closest approach to Jupiter on this day in 1979. It provided crucial data about the giant planet's atmosphere, magnetic field, and moons.
March 4: The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, launched by NASA in 2005, began its orbit around Mars on this day. It has been instrumental in studying the planet's surface, atmosphere, and water-related features.
March 5: On this day in 1979, Voyager 1 made its closest approach to Jupiter, capturing detailed images and data about the gas giant and its moons.
March 6: The space shuttle Columbia completed its final mission, STS-107, on this day in 2003. Tragically, the shuttle disintegrated during re-entry, resulting in the loss of all seven crew members.
March 7: NASA's Mars Rover Curiosity drilled into Martian rock for the first time on this day in 2013. The sample collected provided evidence of past environmental conditions suitable for microbial life.
March 8: The Soviet Union's Venera 3 spacecraft became the first human-made object to impact Venus on this day in 1966. Although communication was lost before reaching the surface, it marked the first landing attempt on another planet.
March 9: The European Space Agency's Rosetta spacecraft rendezvoused with comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko on this day in 2014. It deployed the Philae lander to the comet's surface, marking the first soft landing on a comet.
March 10: NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, launched in 2005, discovered hydrated minerals indicating the presence of liquid water on the Martian surface on this day in 2006. It provided crucial evidence for Mars' watery past.
March 11: The Hubble Space Telescope detected the first evidence of water vapor on the exoplanet K2-18b, a potentially habitable world, on this day in 2015. It raised the possibility of liquid water on distant exoplanets.
March 12: On this day in 2009, the Kepler space telescope discovered its first confirmed exoplanet, named Kepler-7b. It is a gas giant located about 1,000 light-years away from Earth.
March 13: The Soviet Union's Venera 4 spacecraft became the first to enter Venus' atmosphere and transmit data on this day in 1966. It provided valuable information about the planet's composition and atmospheric conditions.
March 14: NASA's MESSENGER spacecraft successfully entered orbit around Mercury on this day in 2011, becoming the first mission to do so. It conducted extensive observations and measurements of the planet until its mission end in 2015.
March 15: The Cassini spacecraft, launched in 1997, made its closest flyby of Saturn's moon Enceladus on this day in 2008. It detected water vapor geysers erupting from the moon's south polar region, suggesting the presence of a subsurface ocean.
March 16: The Gemini 8 mission, conducted by NASA in 1966, achieved the world's first successful docking of two spacecraft. Astronauts Neil Armstrong and David Scott docked their Gemini spacecraft with the Agena target vehicle.
March 17: On this day in 2002, the space shuttle Atlantis made its final docking with the Russian space station Mir. It marked the last time a space shuttle docked with Mir before the station's deorbit and re-entry.
March 18: The Soviet Union's Luna 13 spacecraft became the first human-made object to make a soft landing on the Moon's surface and transmit photographs back to Earth on this day in 1966.
March 19: NASA's Mars rover Opportunity discovered evidence of past water on the Martian surface in the form of sulfate-rich deposits on this day in 2004. It provided further support for the planet's watery past.
March 20: Launched in 1999, the Chandra X-ray Observatory, NASA's flagship X-ray telescope, was deployed by the space shuttle Columbia on this day. It has provided groundbreaking observations of X-ray sources in the universe.
March 21: The Hubble Space Telescope detected the first organic molecule, methane, in the atmosphere of an exoplanet named HD 189733b on this day in 2007. It represented a significant milestone in the study of exoplanet atmospheres.
March 22: On this day in 2001, the Russian space station Mir was deorbited and burned up in the Earth's atmosphere after more than 15 years of service. It marked the end of an era for space exploration.
March 23: The European Space Agency's ExoMars mission, comprising the Trace Gas Orbiter and Schiaparelli lander, was launched on this day in 2016. It aims to study Mars' atmosphere and search for signs of past or present life.
March 24: NASA's Kepler space telescope, launched in 2009, discovered its first exoplanet in the habitable zone of its star on this day in 2011. Known as Kepler-22b, it is located about 600 light-years away and is larger than Earth.
March 25: The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, launched in 2005, captured the first definitive evidence of liquid water flowing on the Martian surface during warmer seasons on this day in 2015. It provided crucial insights into Mars' potential for hosting life.
March 26: On this day in 1979, the space shuttle Columbia completed its first successful mission, STS-1, with astronauts John Young and Robert Crippen aboard. It marked the first orbital spaceflight of the Space Shuttle program.
March 27: The Hubble Space Telescope imaged the spectacular
in the Eagle Nebula on this day in 1995. The image showcases immense columns of gas and dust where new stars are forming.
March 28: NASA's Viking 1 spacecraft made its closest approach to Mars on this day in 1976, providing high-resolution images and conducting experiments to search for signs of life on the Red Planet.
March 29: The European Space Agency's Herschel Space Observatory, launched in 2009, observed a massive ring of dust around the star HR 4796A on this day in 2010. The ring is believed to be a potential planetary formation zone.
March 30: The Apollo 15 mission, launched in 1971, successfully landed on the Moon on this day. Astronauts David Scott and James Irwin conducted three moonwalks and drove the Lunar Roving Vehicle, covering a distance of over 17 miles.
March 31: Launched in 2001, NASA's Mars Odyssey spacecraft entered orbit around Mars on this day. It has been studying the planet's surface, atmosphere, and radiation environment, providing valuable data for future missions.
April 1: The Hubble Space Telescope detected evidence of an extrasolar planet's atmosphere for the first time on this day in 2004. The exoplanet, designated HD 209458b, showed the presence of sodium in its atmosphere.
April 2: NASA's MESSENGER spacecraft made its closest approach to Mercury on this day in 2008, capturing detailed images and data about the planet's surface, composition, and magnetic field.
April 3: Launched in 1989, the Hubble Space Telescope was deployed into space from the space shuttle Discovery on this day. It has since revolutionized our understanding of the universe through its stunning images and groundbreaking discoveries.
April 4: The Soviet Union's Luna 10 spacecraft became the first human-made object to enter orbit around the Moon on this day in 1966. It provided valuable data about the lunar environment from an orbital perspective.
April 5: NASA's Mars Pathfinder mission was launched on this day in 1996. It successfully landed the Sojourner rover on Mars, marking the first successful deployment of a wheeled vehicle on the Martian surface.
April 6: The European Space Agency's Gaia spacecraft, launched in 2013, started its mission to create a detailed 3D map of the Milky Way galaxy on this day. It has been measuring the positions and motions of more than a billion stars.
April 7: On this day in 2001, the space shuttle Discovery completed its mission STS-102, which involved the exchange of crew members on the International Space Station (ISS) and the delivery of supplies and equipment.
April 8: NASA's Kepler space telescope, launched in 2009, discovered its first rocky exoplanet, named Kepler-10b, on this day in 2011. It marked a significant milestone in the search for Earth-like planets beyond our solar system.
April 9: The Apollo 13 mission, launched in 1970, experienced an oxygen tank explosion en route to the Moon. Despite the critical situation, the crew and ground control worked together to safely return the astronauts to Earth.
April 10: The Hubble Space Telescope captured the iconic
image in the Eagle Nebula on this day in 1995. The image showcases towering columns of gas and dust where new stars are being born.
April 11: NASA's Mars Odyssey spacecraft detected hydrogen, a possible sign of water ice, beneath the surface of Mars on this day in 2002. It provided crucial information for future Mars missions and potential human exploration.
April 12: On this day in 1961, Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first human to orbit the Earth aboard the Vostok 1 spacecraft. His historic journey lasted approximately 108 minutes.
April 13: The Hubble Space Telescope observed the collision of Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 with Jupiter on this day in 1994. The impacts of the comet fragments created massive scars on Jupiter's atmosphere.
April 14: NASA's Apollo 16 mission, launched in 1972, successfully landed on the Moon. Astronauts John Young and Charles Duke explored the lunar surface, collected samples, and conducted experiments.
April 15: The European Space Agency's Herschel Space Observatory, launched in 2009, detected water vapor in the atmosphere of a young star-forming region known as the Orion Nebula on this day in 2011.
April 16: NASA's Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft, launched in 1996, entered orbit around Mars on this day. It extensively mapped the planet's surface, analyzed its climate, and studied its magnetic field.
April 17: The space shuttle Discovery completed its final mission, STS-131, on this day in 2010. It delivered supplies and equipment to the International Space Station, marking the end of Discovery's spaceflight career.
April 18: Launched in 1990, the Hubble Space Telescope was deployed into space from the space shuttle Discovery on this day. It has since provided breathtaking images and transformed our understanding of the universe.
April 19: NASA's Kepler space telescope, launched in 2009, discovered the first Earth-sized exoplanet in the habitable zone of its star on this day in 2014. Known as Kepler-186f, it is located about 500 light-years away from Earth.
April 20: The Mars rover Curiosity drilled into Martian rock for the first time on this day in 2013. The sample collected provided valuable insights into Mars' past environmental conditions and its potential for habitability.
April 21: The Hubble Space Telescope imaged the stunning
in the Eagle Nebula on this day in 1995. The image showcases colossal columns of gas and dust where new stars are being born.
April 22: On this day in 2000, the space shuttle Discovery launched the Hubble Space Telescope Servicing Mission 3A, which successfully upgraded and repaired various components of the telescope.
April 23: The European Space Agency's Planck satellite, launched in 2009, released its first all-sky map of the cosmic microwave background radiation on this day in 2010. The map provided insights into the early universe and the formation of structures.
April 24: NASA's Mars rover Opportunity detected clay minerals on the Martian surface for the first time on this day in 2004. The presence of clay indicated the past presence of water and potentially habitable conditions.
April 25: On this day in 1990, the Hubble Space Telescope was deployed into space by the space shuttle Discovery. It has since revolutionized our understanding of the universe through its stunning images and groundbreaking discoveries.
April 26: NASA's Kepler space telescope, launched in 2009, discovered its first exoplanet in the habitable zone of its star on this day in 2011. Known as Kepler-22b, it is located about 600 light-years away and has a size comparable to Earth.
April 27: The space shuttle Atlantis completed its final mission, STS-135, on this day in 2011. It marked the end of the space shuttle program, concluding three decades of shuttle flights.
April 28: The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, launched in 2005, detected hydrated minerals on the slopes of Martian craters on this day in 2008. The discovery provided evidence of water-related processes on the Red Planet.

April 30: The Hubble Space Telescope captured the stunning image of the
in the Eagle Nebula on this day in 1995. The image showcases towering columns of gas and dust where new stars are forming.

May 2: NASA's Kepler space telescope, launched in 2009, confirmed its first exoplanet in the habitable zone of its star on this day in 2011. Known as Kepler-10c, it is a rocky planet with a size about 2.3 times that of Earth.
May 3: The Hubble Space Telescope captured an image of the galaxy cluster Abell 1689 on this day in 2002. The image revealed the gravitational lensing effect, where the cluster's gravity distorts and magnifies the light of more distant galaxies.
May 4: On this day in 1989, the space shuttle Atlantis deployed NASA's Magellan spacecraft, which later mapped the surface of Venus using radar. It provided detailed images and data about the planet's geology.
May 5: The Japanese space probe Hayabusa was launched on this day in 2003. It successfully reached the asteroid Itokawa in 2005, collected samples, and returned them to Earth, marking the first asteroid sample return mission.

(NGC 4676), on this day in 2002. The collision resulted in the formation of long tidal tails of stars.
May 7: NASA's Mars Exploration Rover Spirit successfully landed on Mars on this day in 2004. It operated on the planet's surface for over six years, studying its geology and searching for signs of past water.
May 8: The European Space Agency's Venus Express spacecraft entered orbit around Venus on this day in 2006. It studied the planet's atmosphere, climate, and surface to gain a better understanding of Earth's
May 9: On this day in 2011, NASA's space shuttle Endeavour launched on its final mission, STS-134. The mission delivered the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer and other equipment to the International Space Station.
May 10: The Hubble Space Telescope captured a stunning image of the
(M104) on this day in 2003. The image showcases a bright central bulge surrounded by a prominent dust disk resembling a sombrero.
May 11: NASA's Mars rover Curiosity, part of the Mars Science Laboratory mission, was launched on this day in 2011. It successfully landed on Mars in August 2012 and has been exploring the planet's surface since then.
May 12: The European Space Agency's Herschel Space Observatory, launched in 2009, observed the formation of stars in the Orion Molecular Cloud Complex on this day in 2010. It provided insights into the early stages of star formation.
May 13: NASA's space shuttle Atlantis, launched in 1985, deployed the Magellan spacecraft, which later mapped the surface of Venus using radar. It provided detailed images and data about the planet's geology.

(M51) on this day in 1990. The image revealed intricate details of the galaxy's spiral arms and its interaction with a smaller companion galaxy.
May 16: NASA's Mars rover Opportunity discovered the mineral jarosite on the Martian surface on this day in 2004. The presence of jarosite indicated the past presence of liquid water and potentially habitable conditions.
May 17: The European Space Agency's Rosetta spacecraft, launched in 2004, made its closest approach to asteroid 21 Lutetia on this day in 2010. The flyby provided detailed images and data about the asteroid's composition.
May 18: On this day in 1969, NASA's Apollo 10 mission was launched, serving as a rehearsal for the Apollo 11 Moon landing. The mission tested the lunar module in lunar orbit, coming within just miles of the lunar surface.

in the Eagle Nebula on this day in 1995. The image showcases colossal columns of gas and dust where new stars are forming.

on this day in 1999. The collision resulted in the formation of new stars and altered the galaxies' shapes.
May 25: On this day in 2008, NASA's Phoenix Mars Lander successfully landed near the Martian north pole. It studied the planet's icy soil and searched for evidence of past or present microbial life.
May 26: NASA's New Horizons spacecraft made its closest approach to Pluto on this day in 2015, capturing detailed images and data about the dwarf planet and its moons.
May 27: The Hubble Space Telescope observed a supernova explosion in the galaxy NGC 4526 on this day in 1994. The explosion provided valuable data for understanding the life cycles of stars.
May 28: NASA's Mars Exploration Rover Opportunity discovered strong evidence of ancient water on Mars' Meridiani Planum region on this day in 2004. The discovery indicated the past habitability of the planet.
May 29: The space shuttle Discovery deployed the Hubble Space Telescope on this day in 1990. The telescope has since transformed our understanding of the universe through its breathtaking images and scientific discoveries.

revealing thousands of galaxies in a tiny patch of the sky. It revolutionized our understanding of the universe's vastness.
June 2: NASA's Voyager 1 spacecraft made its closest approach to Saturn on this day in 1981, capturing detailed images and data about the planet and its rings. It provided valuable insights into Saturn's composition and structure.
June 3: The Hubble Space Telescope observed the collision of Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 with Jupiter on this day in 1994. The impacts of the comet fragments created massive scars on Jupiter's atmosphere.

June 5: NASA's Mars rover Curiosity detected organic compounds, including the building blocks of life, in Martian rocks on this day in 2018. The discovery suggested that Mars may have once supported ancient microbial life.
June 6: The European Space Agency's Rosetta spacecraft rendezvoused with comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko on this day in 2014. It later released the Philae lander, marking the first soft landing on a comet's surface.

(M51) on this day in 1990. The image revealed intricate details of the galaxy's spiral arms and its interaction with a smaller companion galaxy.

allowed for excellent views of the Red Planet from Earth.
June 10: NASA's space shuttle Endeavour completed its final mission, STS-134, on this day in 2011. It delivered the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer and other equipment to the International Space Station.
June 11: The Hubble Space Telescope observed the
(NGC 4038/4039) on this day in 1996. The image revealed two colliding galaxies, with their interacting tidal tails of stars and intense star formation.
June 12: On this day in 1981, the space shuttle Columbia became the first space shuttle to be launched into space, marking the beginning of the Space Shuttle Program.
June 13: NASA's Mars rover Opportunity detected evidence of past water on Mars' Endeavour Crater on this day in 2013. The discovery provided further insights into Mars' ancient habitability.
June 14: The European Space Agency's Planck satellite, launched in 2009, released its first all-sky map of the cosmic microwave background radiation on this day in 2010. The map provided insights into the early universe and the formation of structures.
June 15: On this day in 1995, the space shuttle Discovery delivered the Russian-built module, Spektr, to the International Space Station. It increased the station's living and working space.
June 16: The Hubble Space Telescope captured an image of the globular cluster Omega Centauri on this day in 2009. The cluster contains hundreds of thousands of stars and is one of the largest and brightest globular clusters in the Milky Way.
June 17: NASA's Voyager 2 spacecraft made its closest approach to Saturn on this day in 1981, capturing detailed images and data about the planet and its moons. It provided valuable insights into Saturn's complex system.
June 18: On this day in 1983, Sally Ride became the first American woman in space as a crew member of the space shuttle Challenger during the STS-7 mission.
June 19: The Hubble Space Telescope imaged a stunning supernova remnant, known as the
(M1), on this day in 1999. The image showcased the expanding debris from a stellar explosion that occurred in the year 1054.
June 20: On this day in 2008, NASA's Phoenix Mars Lander found water ice on Mars' polar region. The discovery provided further evidence of water on the Red Planet.
June 21: The summer solstice occurs on this day in the northern hemisphere, marking the longest day and shortest night of the year. It is a significant astronomical event related to Earth's axial tilt.
June 22: NASA's space shuttle Discovery launched the Hubble Space Telescope Servicing Mission 3B on this day in 2002. The mission successfully upgraded and repaired various components of the telescope.
June 23: On this day in 2016, the European Space Agency's Gaia spacecraft released its second data catalog, containing precise measurements of over a billion stars in our galaxy.

December 24: On this day in 1968, the Apollo 8 astronauts broadcasted a live television broadcast from lunar orbit, reading from the Book of Genesis and wishing a Merry Christmas to everyone on Earth.
December 25: NASA's space probe Voyager 1 captured the famous
image on this day in 1990. It showed Earth as a tiny, pale blue speck in the vastness of space, highlighting our planet's fragility and interconnectedness.
December 26: The Hubble Space Telescope observed a distant galaxy cluster known as
on this day in 1999. The image revealed multiple instances of gravitational lensing, magnifying and distorting the light from background galaxies.
December 27: On this day in 2004, NASA's Spirit rover successfully landed on the Martian surface, becoming the second Mars Exploration Rover to explore the Red Planet.
December 28: The European Space Agency's Gaia spacecraft released its third data catalog, providing precise measurements of billions of stars in our galaxy, on this day in 2020.
December 29: On this day in 2006, NASA's New Horizons spacecraft made its closest approach to Jupiter, using the planet's gravity to gain speed for its mission to study Pluto and the Kuiper Belt.
December 30: The Hubble Space Telescope captured an image of the
in the Carina Nebula (NGC 3372) on this day in 2010. The image showcased a towering pillar of gas and dust, sculpted by the intense stellar winds and radiation.
December 31: On this day in 1999, NASA's Mars Polar Lander, designed to study the Martian polar regions, was scheduled to land on Mars but unfortunately lost contact shortly before its landing.
